review.title: Matching Media Contents with User Profiles by means of the Dempster-Shafer Theory
review.abstract: The media industry is increasingly personalizing the offering of contents in attempt to better target the audience. This requires to analyze the relationships that goes established between users and content they enjoy, looking at one side to the content characteristics and on the other to the user profile, in order to find the best match between the two. In this paper we suggest to build that relationship using the Dempster-Shafer's Theory of Evidence, proposing a reference model and illustrating its properties by means of a toy example. Finally we suggest possible applications of the model for tasks that are common in the modern media industry.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we have examined a preference model based on the Dempster-Shafer theory and its application to the media industry, which is an evolution of what has been done so far by introducing some elements of novelty, including the ability to include the user profile as part of the conclusion, rather than being neutral in relation to various applications and problems discussed in the previous section. There are still some issues that need to be resolved. Most important is the scalability of the model. In fact, the nature of D-S theory is inherently combinatorial, so that the search space explodes by including more elements in the overall dimension. The possibility of defining equivalence classes in terms of belief and plausibility is one way to reduce complexity, but more work needs to be done to make this solution feasible in practice. Furthermore, the model presented here needs to be validated by validating other elements within the overall dimension.
